item.title: Comment on Saturday assorted links by rayward
item.description:
1. "[T]o bring people closer to God." Years ago in my church, the Episcopal Church, and in the Roman Catholic Church, the reformists began a redesign of the interior of the building, moving the altar from the front wall out close to the congregation, the idea being to bring the people closer to God. But does it?

The area around the altar and cross is called the "sanctuary". I suppose the sanctuary was removed from the people when it was at the wall, but when the "sanctuary" was moved out among the people, the "sanctuary" became more like the cashier at Walmart than the sacred place inhabited by God. When the sanctuary was separated, it was a mystical place: one could feel the presence of God in this special, separate space, that only a few could enter. I was an acolyte, so I was allowed in this sacred space, and I felt it. I still do in the churches with the traditional design. I've argued with young priests about this who only know the new design. but when I say that the new design has diminished the sacred place of the sanctuary, as anybody can and does wander around the altar like the cashier at Walmart. Does it matter? For those who have a "personal relationship" with God, I suppose not. Pray tell.

item.title: Comment on The Financial Consequences of Legalized Sports Gambling by Naveen K
item.description:
It's amazing how many libertarian ideas very recently have come to pass either by actual legalization or de facto legalization and none of them have had the positive effects libertarians told us they would have.

In fact, they have been actively and demonstrably harmful as this study indicates and none of their positive effects have come to pass.

- De-facto drug legalization in West Coast cities have been a disaster.
- Even drug legalization of marijuana has been a disaster. I witnessed it on ground zero in Denver. Read Charles Fain Lehman's excellent NYT piece on what a disaster marijuana legalization has been.
- Conservatives are complicit in this but reduced gun control has been shown to causally increase self-harm and suicide rates in many studies. Though gun control reduction has only had a modest or insignificant effect on gun crime.
- Criminal justice reform as implemented by fellow travelers with libertarians on this, the progressives have been a disaster as well (de-policing, eliminating cash bail, reducing sentences for violent crime, making felonies into misdemeanors). Though Alex to his credit has called for more police. Just look at everywhere from SF, LA, Oakland, and DC to Philadelphia where Soros-funded progressive prosecutors and DAs have taken office (or previously held office).
- Now, legalized gambling is having a significant impact on the financial health of young men as this study shows. Ignore the 0.3% credit score decrease. It’s a devastating study that shows significant effect sizes for other financial harms.

Libertarians keep selling on magical benefits of lifting prohibition on vices but when they are lifted society remembers why these vices were banned in the first place.

Conservatives should govern like conservatives and remember they are not libertarians though their worldviews overlap. Libertarians should listen to this excellent podcast episode by Charles Fain Lehman titled The Libertarian Case for Drug Prohibition on the Charles C.W. Cooke podcast.
